alert.note: Alert for Harris (Texas) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flash Flood Warning issued January 09 at 1:18AM CST until January 09 at 3:00AM CST by NWS Houston - Galveston
info.description: The National Weather Service in League City has extended the * Flash Flood Warning for... Harris County in southeastern Texas... * Until 300 AM CST. * At 118 AM CST, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing heavy rain across the warned area. Between 3 and 5 inches of rain have fallen across portions of the warned area. The expected rainfall rate is 1 to 2 inches in 30 minutes. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly. The Houston Fire Department reports multiple active water rescues on flooded roadways in the warned area. Avoid travel and remain in shelter. HAZARD...Life threatening flash flooding. Thunderstorms producing flash flooding. SOURCE...Radar. IMPACT...Life threatening flash flooding of creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses. * Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Humble, Jersey Village, Greater Greenspoint, Aldine, Spring, northwestern Northside / Northline, Kingwood, Hidden Valley, Bush Intercontinental Airport, Acres Home, Greater Inwood, Splashtown, Willowbrook, Independence Heights, Central Northwest, Fairbanks / Northwest Crossing, Langwood, Lazybrook / Timbergrove, Spring Branch East and Lake Houston. This includes the following Low Water Crossings... Hardy Toll Road and Rankin Road, Deer Trail Drive at Halls Bayou, Gulf Bank Road at tributary of Halls Bayou, Granville Drive at Little White Oak Bayou, Beltway 8 at JFK, Beltway 8 at Hardy Toll Road, Interstate 45 at 1960, Interstate 45 at Beltway 8 North, Interstate 45 at Greens, Sunnywood Drive at Halls Bayou and Dillard Street just west of N Shepherd Dr. FLASH FLOOD...RADAR INDICATED FLASH FLOOD DAMAGE THREAT...CONSIDERABLE EXPECTED RAINFALL RATE...1-2 INCHES IN 30 MINUTES
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the dangers of flooding.
